page.title: 15THE RECTOR OF WADDINGTON
page.content: In February 1982 I was inducted as Rector and received with great warmth and friendliness and two hour peel of bells. One of the earliest excitements was the view, from Waddington 'Cliff', over the Trent Valley with the massive power stations a constant reminder that in the 1970s every village in the land had become 'urban'. Farming and employment has changed radically and patterns of behaviour have been offered to us in bewildering profusion. People here, as elsewhere, are less ready to respond to direct instruction and more ready to respond to learn through questioning and experiencing. Hence the development of church house groups and a more informal style of meeting and worship. There is a shift from passivity under authority to expectations of collaboration and sharing.
